2. A 10-year-old female is brought to the neurology clinic due to a two-year history of increasingly unsteady walking and frequent tripping. Her parents note that she has developed stiffness and tightness in her legs, making it difficult for her to run or climb stairs without assistance. Additionally, she has experienced mild dysarthria and occasional hand tremors. On neurological examination, she demonstrates spasticity in the lower limbs, brisk deep tendon reflexes, and a wide-based, unsteady gait with evident limb ataxia. Sensory examination is intact, and there are no signs of cognitive impairment. Her developmental milestones were normal until symptom onset, and there is a history of consanguinity in the family. MRI of the brain reveals cerebellar atrophy, predominantly affecting the vermis. Genetic testing identifies biallelic mutations in the SYNE1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of autosomal recessive spastic ataxia 2.
